title: 103_hr2170
content: The Act titled "Omnibus Nuclear Power Safety and Security Enhancement Act of 1993" amends the Energy Reorganization Act of 1974 to include notification requirements regarding noncompliance. The Act requires immediate notification to the Commission if a facility or component fails to comply with regulations and poses a safety hazard. The Act mandates prompt notification to the Commission of any defects or failures to comply with regulations at a facility. The Commission has the authority to issue regulations and orders to ensure compliance, including penalties for non-compliance. The Act requires individuals employed by entities subject to reporting requirements to be aware of and comply with notification obligations. The Commission can conduct inspections and enforcement activities to ensure compliance with regulations. The term 'person' in this context refers to entities subject to the reporting requirements. The term 'person' in this section includes the Department of Energy and individuals who are sole proprietors, partners, directors, or responsible officers of businesses involved in regulated activities. This section applies to the United States Enrichment Corporation and its leased facilities. The section applies to the United States Enrichment Corporation, its facilities, directors, and officers, to the same extent as any other person. Civil monetary penalties may be imposed for violations of rules, regulations, orders, or licensing requirements. Section 234 a. of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to include penalties for violations of licensing provisions, certification provisions, terms of licenses, and rules or orders issued under specific sections. Violations may result in license revocation under section 186. The Commission may impose a civil penalty of up to $100,000 for each violation under section 186. Each day of a continuing violation will be considered a separate violation for penalty calculation purposes. The Commission has the authority to adjust or waive these penalties. Amendments are made to the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 to include civil monetary penalties for violations of rules, regulations, orders, or licensing requirements. "Sec. 234. Civil monetary penalties for violations of rules, regulations, orders, or licensing requirements. SEC. 4. ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON REACTOR SAFEGUARDS. Section 29 of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended by striking the last 2 sentences. SEC. 5. CARRYING OF FIREARMS BY LICENSEE EMPLOYEES." SEC. 5. CARRYING OF FIREARMS BY LICENSEE EMPLOYEES. The Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to allow licensee employees to carry firearms at facilities owned or contracted by the United States or licensed by the Commission. SEC. 6. Unauthorized introduction of dangerous weapons. Section 229 a. of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to include licensing authority under this Act or any other Act. SEC. 7. Sabotage of production, utilization, or waste storage facilities under construction. Section 236 a. of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to address intentional destruction or damage to licensed production, utilization, or waste storage facilities, as well as nuclear fuel and spent nuclear fuel. Under this Act, intentional destruction or damage to licensed nuclear facilities, nuclear fuel, or spent nuclear fuel can result in a fine of up to $10,000 or imprisonment for up to 10 years, or both. SEC. 8. ADMINISTRATIVE SEARCH WARRANTS. Section 161 c. of the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 is amended to authorize the Commission to conduct studies, investigations, hold meetings, administer oaths, issue subpoenas, and conduct searches without a warrant for the purpose of exercising its authority under the Act. The Commission is authorized to conduct searches with a warrant under the Energy Reorganization Act of 1974. Before issuing a warrant, the Commission must have reasonable suspicion of a violation. Searches must be directly related to the warrant and conducted promptly. Witnesses subpoenaed under paragraph (1)(B) must be paid the same fees and mileage as witnesses in US district courts.
